oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lucknow, Home of John J. Craig
Melrose, Home of Oliver P. Temple
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Garden Study Club of Nashville, Parthenon Press
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three story Italianate villa located on a tree-filled hill.

This fashionable house, designed by an unknown architect, was commissioned by John J. Craig, a prominent businessman originally from Alabama, who was engaged in mercantile and banking activities just prior to the Civil War. Like several of his Unionist peers, Craig moved away from the city in the early years of the war. With his wife, Knoxvillian Mary Lyon, and their infant son, he relocated to Cincinnati and later to New York while conflict raged in Tennessee. Another well-known Knoxville Unionist, Oliver P. Temple, purchased the house in 1865 and renamed it Melrose. After the war, Craig returned to Knoxville and founded one of Tennessee's largest marble companies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Craig, John J. -- Homes and haunts; Temple, Oliver Perry, 1820-1907 -- Homes and haunts; Architecture, Domestic
Taking Care of Business
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
